The conventions used to be more fun, especially the Democratic ones. Like in 1968, when Mayor Daley of Chicago entertained America with his police beating up and tear gassing war protesters and the mayor himself cursing a United States Senator from the safety of the Illinois delegation.
Then we had the famous 1924 convention in Madison Square Garden (the old site at Madison Avenue and East 27 Street) which had 104 ballots, give or take, and was highlighted when a bunch of Yankee Democrats not thrilled with a nominee from the south marched around the convention floor singing: "While We Were Marching Through Georgia", a song commemorating General Sherman's March To The Sea.
Now the conventions are nothing more than one big campaign ad paid for by the American people. If the Dems had a little chutzpah, they would drive a station wagon on to the convention floor with a dog in a crate tied to the car's roof.

While the Germans have been quite honest about their WWII crimes, nobody wants to mention comparable Japanese crimes. Some of them were actually much worse than enslaving Korean women...

Sounds as if that is exactly what happened, real investors ran for the hills.  I mean do they really believe FB is worth more than HP and Cisco?   Are we that stupid?   I don't think so and the market proved it.

As an ex-Wall Streeter ( now retired) all I have to say is buyer beware.

The only truth is that the future is unknowable.

The VCs are all about probablities. They have a pool of capital. They have a few winners and mostly losers. The returns on the winners make up for the losses on the losers.

Their own personal stakes (known as carried interest) are taxed at lower capital gains tax rates, even though they themselves commit zero capital. Only their investors (known as limited partners) commit the capital.

That folks is the gig. Do you really think an ordinary retail investor can really outsmart these investors with the cards stacked in their favor ? While there may be exceptions, the general rule is that when the VCs are selling (called making distributions) do not buy, but run for the hills!

I think I have the beginning of a demonstration for the impossibility of a spherical triangle with heights Ha:Hb:Hc=1:2:3. The sides are abc and the angles are αβγ.

From the sine law applied to heights, we know sin(γ) = sin(α) * sin(1x)/sin(3x). Since, as Hans pointed out we shouldn’t accept supplementary angles, the largest height 3x 180, but in the best case scenario we have just reviewed, α + β + γ = 90 + 48.6 +30 = 168.6 < 180. Therefore we have to conclude that there is no non-trick triangle with the desired heights.

@Gerry: thanks you said this better than I could have. Of course I adamantly oppose anyone being forced into "reparative therapy" (especially children and teens) or shamed into going.

However, trying to turn this into a witch hunt is grossly unfair, and a sign of how lefty liberal political correctness manages to destroy ANY kind of individual thought or research.

The real fact is that gays have become exponentially more powerful in the past decade -- enough to turn the President into a bald-faced liar who suddenly flips on his commitment to traditional marriage. There is a vast amount of power at play here, and a lot of people with vast amounts of money, who want to not just have gays and lesbians free to live as they wish, but to actually give them more rights and more power (especially to sue!) than other people.

If it's always fine to "want to live as a homosexual" (and I believe it is), then why isn't fine to choose to live as a heterosexual? If an outwardly straight person decides he or she is homosexual, it is treated as liberation, and cause for inner happiness. Choose heterosexuality, and you are automatically "lying", and any therapist who helps you is "a criminal".

Psychopathic killers and "functional" alcoholics don't experience functional impairment or distress? It sounds like you don't know anybody who fits these categories. As a therapist, I can tell you these individuals are definitley "impaired" and, at least in the functional alcoholic's case, are "distressed" every time they ruin a family party or wake up with a screaming hang-over after an alcoholic binge. To say nothing of the family dysfunction these conditions cause. And come on - sexuality is behavior? As with alcoholism, there are certainly genetic and biological components to human sexuality. Howver, the difference between an alcoholic and a homosexual individual who has accepted his/her orientation is night and day. Embracing one's innate sexual identify brings a sense of wholeness and fulfilment, something an alchoholic doesn't experience until he/she gives up the very thing they crave.

See where you are coming from.  Let's just examine your third assertion regarding alcoholism.  Indeed, few infants are alcoholics - perhaps it's because few of them have ready access to liquor, but anyone who has done any work in the field of addiction recognizes that there is often a genetic predisposition to addictive behaviors.  So you have chosen to ignore completely neurobiology and genetics in order to posit your theory that all gays and drinkers and druggies "choose" to be gay or drunk or high.  I can only hope that you work in a bologna factory.

There are several problems with your statement, "he compared homosexuality with other disorders...like depression and alcohol dependence....and saw that the latter caused marked distress or impairment, while homosexuality often did not."

1) Lack of marked distress is not a good reason to remove a diagnostic category. Child abusers, sociopaths, and psychopathic killers also do not experience marked distress or impairment over their behavior but they have not been removed from the DSM.

2) Some homosexuals do experience distress as a result of their attractions and they are only offered "gay affirming" due largely to the efforts of LGBT's within the APA to stifle research and therapeutic alternatives.

3) Sexuality is behavior. Like alcoholism, no one is born alcoholic or chooses to become an alcoholic. Alcoholics do not necessarily experience marked distress over their condition or impairment....hence the term "functional alcoholic."

4) Why should it be threatening, or demeaning, or insulting, to provide a full range of therapeutic options so that everyone has a real choice.....not one that is dictated to them by others?

Thank you for this. I couldn't have put it better. I remember reading the article referred to in this piece (written by a man who had gone through "reparative therapy" as a teenager), and Dr. Spitzer is pretty clear in that article that the question he was really interested in was whether it's really impossible for someone's sexual orientation to change. It's probably pretty darn *near* impossible, but that's not necessarily the same thing. So I can understand his fascination with the original question. His study was flawed, and was horribly misused by people and groups who are and were motivated by prejudice, but those sins were theirs, not his.

Some pretty negative responses to Dr. Spitzer's apology here, I see, and some positive. I, for one, am not too concerned what motivated Dr. Spitzer to write a retraction, but am thankful that he has. I am not gay myself, but I have many loved ones, friends and family, that are, and there is nothing wrong with them that needs "reparative" therapy!

That seems awfully harsh. I admire his strength to apologize. I don't think Dr. Spitzer ever displayed any homophobia or hatred or bigotry that you described. He did make a mistake by labeling homosexuality as a disease and acknowledged the wrong in that, but ultimately he was searching to provide the option to homosexuals to potentially convert to heterosexuality. I don't think that giving people that choice is a bad thing at all or suggests that being homosexual requires treatment. There are many homosexuals who would choose to take such a hypothetical treatment if it existed. His big mistake was labeling it as a disease, suggesting that the treatment was not simply an option but a necessity for acceptance.

Long story short, don't blame the gunsmith. Blame the gunner who misuses it.
Sexuality is not behavior, it is inherent.  Alcoholism is considered a disease, while homosexuality is not. There are no common traits between the two and is a mistake to compare the two.

We are a combination of natural and environmental factors.  It seems very unfair of you to say that, based on your cousin, we are not influenced by external factors.  Could it be that bisexuality is natural, and we are generally forced one way or another by our experiences?  I don't know, but at the same time, I would never claim to know.

If an alcoholic does not change his or her behavior, he or she may die of the effects of the substance.  If one has sex with a member of one's own sex, what happens is the same thing that happens with any sex: it could be an expression of love, of intimacy, it could be, like much heterosexual sex, merely having a good time.  Protected sex (with a condom) between two consenting adults will not make you sick like an overdose of alcohol. Much to the contrary.

How difficult is that for the "great" man? He apologizes. He was wrong. He admits it when a journalist confronts him. Not before.

Were there any suicides whose motives were enforced by his spurious claims?

He notes that psychiatrists don't recant about interpretations of published data when they're wrong. He wants credit because he recognizes and admits he screwed up – and that's it? What an ego.

An admission of error does nothing to mitigate the damage he's done. The motivation for the apology – coming when he's fading, seems more about his desire to be clear of his error than to seek any sort of active role in trying to help those he's damaged.

I hope the law provides for those effected to bring suits seeking damages. He needs to pay for his errors, not just apologize for them.

I believe that people who refuse to accept a true and heartfelt apology are very likely people who have a very difficult time, or even find it impossible, to offer a true apology for their own mistakes.
Dr. Spitzer only said that change might be possible, not that it was desirable. I think there are many others who need to apologize for making value judgements.

The story was about an elderly, prominent man wishing to right something within his own heart, that might ease the hearts of those adversely affected by his earlier work. Sadly, his work lead him to the ageless question of homosexuality. This ain't really the the point of the article... It's about a man wishing to leave this earth "clean". Whether he does or not is given to history.

I feel the same way about heterosexuality.  The only time I would object to it would be if it's used to intentionally hurt others, and I don't need to cite any examples. The people here can probably think of a number of them without any prodding.

Fascinating story.  I never knew about Dr. Spitzer and his study.  I don't agree with it, of course, as I don't believe homosexuality is a disorder or a disease or an abomination.  It simply just is.  The only time I would object to it would be if it's used to intentionally hurt others, and I don't need to cite any examples.  The people here can probably think of a number of them without any prodding.

I see there's a huge amount of anger for these charlatan types of "cures" and the pain they've caused. Can't say I blame you.

But full gay rights is finally within arms reach. Very recently it would have been absurd to expect that. Let's remember the damaged lives but also move ahead in reconciliation and forgiveness. Forgive my platitudes, but I think this is a wonderful way to cap off an incredible couple weeks in civil rights history.
Gerry writes "Sexuality is behavior."  Nonsense.  Sexuality is innate and expresses itself in behaviours which are, to some extent, socially determined.

I am a scientist and I find several items cringe worthy:

1) the original article was not peer-reviewed. How could such a controversial article be published and not be reviewed? It impacted so many peoples lives at a personal level and also influenced research career trajectories. It is just so wrong ethically. It smacks of gross professional misconduct by his colleagues. A careful look at this field of research is warranted, if this how it is conducted typically.

2) the amount of time that has passed and his failure to speak up. I know many scientists that carry their flag, never admitting wrong, even when it is so clear. This sets everyone back and hurts the good people that speak up and jeopardize their careers for the greater good and what is ethically right. It takes courage to admit failure when you have skin in the game. Dr Spitzer's apology is necessary, but not courageous--he had nothing to lose.

When I was a medical intern in Chicago in 1990, a psychiatrist held a small group discussion with us to teach us about various common psychiatric conditions.  He mentioned homosexuality.  I raised my hand and interjected that the American Psychiatric Association does not consider homosexuality a disorder.  I didn't let up until he acknowledged that this was true. He then said, "Well, it's not normal," and I said, "Define normal." He was embarrassed and tried to say something about not being able to have a family life with children and therefore not being able to be happy and fulfilled, but I could tell by the looks on the faces of my fellow interns that my point had prevailed.  Thank you, Dr. Spitzer, for allowing me that small moment of dignity.  So you slipped up a bit in your methodology later.  I've slipped up from time to time too.  I now teach residents and fellows that acknowledging mistakes is essential to becoming a good doctor.  Dr. Spitzer, it seems you're a great doctor, right up to the end.  I for one accept your apology.

So another homophobe wrote a dopey book about "reversion" therapy, or whatever you want to call it. We're used to it, and my feelings weren't hurt, either. His apology is his own drama, not ours. Before I came out at 53, I had already landed at many "flight decks" where I would attempt to discuss my "sexual preference problem" with homophobic psychiatrists, then later in psychoanalysis — with a "straight" Jungian who wore a velour jumpsuit and dotted his "i's" with smiley faces — from the 60s through the equally repressed Reagan era. Finally I took matters into my own hands — bleeding chunk though I was — and finally now in 2012 live "out" and free of tacky, telltale Catholic guilt and all my dull relatives scorning voices have ceased. Whether he had written the book or not, I still had to evolve out of a 19th century European upbringing — with yes, singing nuns — to begin living the healthy life now that had been denied me by my own confusion and inner homophobia.
